Sam Leeds.Action: Shoots a man in self-defense, kicks gun aside to prevent further violence.
Speaks tauntingly and smugly to Joe after the shooting incident.
Claps miner on shoulder in a menacing way but miner smiles and calls him friend.
Smiles and speaks in a friendly tone, acknowledges miner as a friend.
Interrupts Sally to pay later and engages in polite breakfast exchange.
Expresses enthusiasm about leaving town and exploring other places despite Sally's unhappiness.
Honestly tells Sally he is not an honest man and admits to being a taker, not a maker.
Asks Sally to come with him despite admitting he won’t be honest, showing openness and sincerity about his flaws.
Turns away from Sally while speaking, and shows irritation when she expresses her desires, indicating emotional distance and lack of empathy.
Accuses Sally and exits angrily when she rejects his lifestyle and desires, showing intolerance and frustration.
Drops his gun calmly instead of escalating conflict with Joe.
Wipes blood from his mouth and exits sullenly without lashing out.
Shows reluctant acceptance of being expelled without resistance.
Refuses to leave without his gun, implying a distrust or guardedness.
Stops riding, dismounts, and stares off stunned at the scene of tragedy
Kneels beside Jehu, takes hold of Jehu's hat brim with care
Listens intently and shows horror upon learning about the Apache threat
Responds affirmatively to Jehu's plea to warn the town
Stops and stares off, stunned, after seeing the aftermath of the attack.
Kneels by Jehu, listens carefully, and acknowledges the threat by promising to warn the town.
Tries to calm nervous horse as it snorts nervously
Kicks horse in the flank causing it to start running
Mounts horse quickly and rides fast toward a destination, showing decisiveness and readiness.
Rides forward in a potentially hostile environment with Indians nearby aiming rifles and giving warnings, maintains focus and movement without panic.
No evident response to Indians aiming rifles or their presence; continues riding toward stagecoach.
Pleading with Sally and others to believe his truth about the Mescaleros and the Indians killing Betty and her girls
Showing sincerity and honesty by insisting he is not lying about the danger
Refusing to leave the town despite threats and hostility
Almost shouting at Joe and visibly distressed during confrontation
Not retaliating aggressively despite being forcibly removed and struggling only to resist
Warns about Mescalero threat with reason and urgency, insists on the truth, and tries to inform townspeople despite hostility.
Refuses to leave town despite danger and community rejection, leading to being forcibly removed by townsmen.
Shows fury grabbing Joe's coat and glaring after him, reacting to the ambush and death of two girls.
Listens to Sally's honest confession, responds calmly and understandingly.
Takes Sally in his arms and kisses her ardently, showing affection.
Expresses impatience or discomfort when confronted about past events ('Oh, why do we have to talk about all this?').
Follows Sally when she pulls away disturbed and angry, indicating concern.
Responds calmly and patiently to Sally's emotional confrontation, shows understanding without defensiveness.
Engages in close, intimate conversation and maintains composure despite tension, indicating emotional control.
Appears reluctant or avoids deeper discussion about his past mistakes or actions ('Oh, why do we have to talk about all this?').
Questions and challenges the Mayor's decision to delay getting water, showing concern for the needs of the community.
Expresses frustration toward the inaction of others ('If there were ten real men here...'), implying criticism of their courage or commitment.
States they want water for the women and kids, expressing concern for their well-being.
Sneers while riding ahead of the wagon, showing smugness.
Tells Joe he told the boys that Joe would say there was no chance of getting water, showing honesty and straightforwardness.
Mounted ahead of the wagon, confidently leading and sneering, showing readiness to confront danger.
Engages in tense dialogue with Joe, indicating awareness of risks but determined to proceed despite warnings.
Displays smugness rather than strategic reconsideration when warned about bushwhacking and danger to the group.
States the group’s minds are made up without showing signs of reconsideration or flexibility.
Gives clear instructions to men to fill the barrels and keep watch while drinking at the river, remains calm when alerted by Griffin about a potential Indian threat.
Successfully goes out and retrieves water when others were too scared.
Boasts about his fearless action to get water, indicating confidence.
Reactively shouts commands to whip the horses upon spotting Apaches, demonstrating alertness and quick response.
Stands up and helps Griffin to his feet despite Griffin's disdain.
Acknowledges the roughness of the environment and the need to take care of oneself, showing practical understanding.
Openly admits to gambling, drinking, and killing in self-defense, demonstrating self-awareness and realism.
Attempts to build rapport by offering a handshake despite being rejected.
Engages in defensive and confrontational dialogue with Griffin instead of de-escalating tension or offering a more thoughtful response.
Admits he never really cared about the town needing water but wanted to impress Sally and make a fool out of Joe, later wishes he could tell her he was wrong
Hugs Griffin happily upon seeing soldiers arrive
Shares water with Griffin and other soldiers, drinks with them
Engages in conversation with soldiers and Griffin about recent events without boasting
Engages in a serious conversation showing self-awareness about past mistakes and a desire to change, expresses hope and attempts to inspire trust in Sally.
Arrested for a kindness, indicating a failure in judgment or circumstances beyond his control.
Urgently urges Sally to run and save herself despite his own peril.
Strives to free himself while encouraging Sally, showing concern for her safety over his own.
Knocks an Indian from horse to protect others, races toward church safety.
Attempts to persuade others to remove his handcuffs so he can fight and help defend everyone.
Stoops by children, does magic tricks to entertain them, helping divert their fear and sadness.
Speaks gently to Sally, urging her to comfort children, encouraging kindness.
Fires a gun at an attacking Indian during conflict.
Expresses concern about the enemy's rituals and communicates this to Joe Madden to prepare for an attack.
Takes on the responsibility of replacing Joe as lookout despite some hesitation.
Suggests lighting up the whole place for better safety instead of just keeping kids away from the firelight.
Proposes that women hold the candles so men can fight, showing practical division of roles but also implying traditional gender roles.
Suggests improving visibility by lighting up the whole place to fight better
Proposes let the women hold the candles to allow men to fight, showing practical problem-solving
Does not directly address the challenge of fighting in the dark himself beyond suggesting candleholders
Performs capably in a difficult situation, remains alert and ready by raising his rifle when a threat appears, listens carefully and coordinates with others.
Engages in calm communication with Pedro-Peter, using inquiry to gather necessary information about the approaching Indians and their needs.
Looks at watch and assesses timing of Colonel Haven's arrival, waits with others showing situational awareness.
Expresses hope that Joe is a good doctor or the Indian a good horse, showing concern but limited influence or proactive planning.
Suddenly opens church door against warning, resulting in Joe being attacked.
Holds gun ready, looks tense but ready as shots are fired, engages in brief, thoughtful conversation about a grim situation
Expresses uncertainty about what to tell others and whether he should tell them, shows hesitation in communication
Shoots a man who reaches for his gun, then quickly kicks gun aside to prevent further threat.
Stands alert with gun ready after confrontation, showing preparedness and confidence.
Motions to a lamp with kerosene dripping after the shooting to indicate evidence and justifies his actions to the mayor and townsmen.
Puts gun away and puts on coat with a taunting and smug attitude after being cleared by the law.
Taunts Joe Madden about putting the matter to the citizens after being legally cleared, possibly indicating overconfidence or provoking trouble.
Engages in a sharp exchange with Joe but does not escalate hostility, simply accepts leaving town.
Makes a parting remark to Joe implying loneliness, shows mild friendliness or concern.
Engages in verbal sparring confidently, acknowledges being unwelcome but asserts his own capabilities.
Accepts being forced to leave town without resistance.
Refuses to be intimidated and remains composed during confrontation.
Enters the cafe confidently and moves forward among the miners having breakfast.
Urgently invites Sally to come with him, acknowledging past fun together.
Follows Sally into the kitchen and tries to engage closely despite her unhappiness.
Offers to have Reverend Griffin marry them if that is what Sally means.
Expresses enthusiasm about visiting other towns and trying their luck after the shooting incident.
Attempts to persuade Sally to come with him and suggests a quick marriage arranged by Reverend Griffin to solve relationship issues.
Seems to be annoyed and glares when Sally moves away and does not engage positively.
Claims to have acquired money fairly from Roy Warren playing Monte, despite Roy's doubtful opinion and subsequent death.
Admits honestly to his nature as a 'taker' rather than a 'maker', showing self-awareness but also a resignation to not working hard or playing by honest rules.
Rejects the idea of being good and honest, contrasting himself negatively with his hardworking father who died broke, which implies a lack of personal drive toward effective or ethical competence.
Confidently asks Sally to come with him despite warning signs about his lifestyle and future prospects, showing some degree of assertiveness but possibly overconfidence or poor judgment.
Dismisses Sally's desire for home and stability as dull and tame, demonstrates cynicism and a lack of emotional intelligence or practical vision, which may undermine relational competence.
Admits to not being honest but sincerely tells Sally this and asks her to come with him.
Dismisses Sally's desire for stability and an honest husband as dull and tame, comparing it disdainfully to Joe Madden.
Acknowledges he is starting to understand more about the situation and decides to stick around despite the odds.
Honestly admits to Sally that he is a taker, not a maker, and reflects on his family background and values with self-awareness.
Expresses willingness to stick around despite recognizing that the odds (cards stacked against him) are not in his favor.
Displays frustration and anger toward Sally when she rejects him, somewhat undermining his emotional control.
Misjudges Sally's desires, initially dismissing her wants as 'mane-stupid' before beginning to understand the situation.
Is nonchalant and ignores Joe's warning about leaving town.
Engages in argument and provokes Joe, leading to physical confrontation.
Leans casually against porch post watching off, indicating relaxed but alert demeanor.
Approaches Joe at the blacksmith shop in a nonchalant manner, suggesting confidence but possible underestimation of the situation.
Is suddenly struck and knocked off scene by Joe with a blow to the jaw, showing he was caught off guard or lacked readiness.
Argues that no legal charges can hold against him, demonstrating awareness of legal boundaries and confidence in his position.
Prepares to draw his gun after being ordered to leave, indicating readiness to confront conflict but possibly rash in escalation.
Starts to pull gun during confrontation showing readiness and awareness.
Drops gun to the ground and exits sullenly without resisting further.
Wipes blood from his mouth indicating physical resilience.
Engages in verbal exchange with Joe, questioning being sent out without his gun.
Accepts being ordered to leave town and compliance without further conflict or rebellion.
Agrees to warn the town despite nervousness and quickly moves to take action.
Looks about nervously and hesitates before rising and acting.
Does not verbally comfort or engage others, shows no explicit friendly or sincere interaction in the excerpt.
Replies shortly but agrees to warn the town promptly.
Looks about nervously and hesitates before moving forward.
Acts quickly to mount horse and ride off to carry out his task.
Hurries forward and urgently warns Joe and others about an imminent danger despite being ignored initially.
Only came back to warn people about the Mescalero Indians, risking his own safety.
Hurries forward and urgently warns Joe about the approaching Mescalero Indians after barely making it back, showing awareness and timely caution.
Tries to communicate a critical warning but is initially ignored by Joe, indicating possible lack of immediate influence or authority.
Rises to one knee and looks off grimly, puts on hat, and exits with determined posture.
Grabs Joe's coat and shows furious, commanding presence, forcing Joe to exit.
Rises to one knee and looks off grimly, puts on hat, prepares to act amid chaos and danger.
Grabs Joe’s coat furiously after discovering bodies in the coach, shows quick recognition of a serious threat but may react emotionally.
Holds Sally closer and kisses her ardently, speaks softly to her.
Expresses frustration when Sally is disturbed and angry, but follows her to the door.
Admits he wouldn’t try to talk to Joe because he believes Joe wouldn’t believe him; acknowledges even Sally doubts his truthfulness.
No direct action, statement, or behavior by Sam Leeds visible in the excerpt; reliance on others' judgments about others' competence
Tries to negotiate with Pedro-Peter and encourages him to drink beer despite social and legal restrictions.
Defiantly gives up his own beer to Pedro-Peter and challenges the men at the table by sitting with them when it is against the law to serve liquor to Indians.
Questions the Mayor's decision about waiting for the patrol, implying impatience and frustration with the delay.
Criticizes group decision-making but does not offer alternative plans or solutions, mostly complains about the situation.
Volunteers to lead a dangerous water-fetching mission, successfully rallies men to volunteer, confidently organizes the group to get going.
Dismisses Griffin's objections and downplays the danger involved in the mission, might underestimate the risks.
Flippant and dismissive toward Sally's concerns, fails to engage meaningfully with criticism which could be important for sound decision-making.
Accepts a gun and bandoleer from Joe and Pedro-Peter without hesitation, thanks them sincerely.
Responds to Reverend Griffin with acknowledgment and practical acceptance, showing trust and cooperation.
Rides ahead leading others, indicating responsibility and willingness to guide the group.
Accepts a rifle and bandoleer from Joe and Pedro-Peter and confidently leads the party on horseback ahead.
Decides to continue the dangerous journey despite warnings of potential Indian ambush from Reverend Griffin, showing resolve but also some risk-taking.
Encourages men to take a good drink and then refill barrels, showing care for their wellbeing and teamwork.
Jokes lightly about Indians not being present ('They must be lookin' the other way, eh?'), maintaining a calm and reassuring demeanor for the men.
Jokes with Reverend Griffin about honesty, showing a friendly, self-deprecating humor.
Boasts about his courage compared to the Mayor's cowardice.
Encourages men to whip their horses and prepare to face danger, taking a proactive leadership role.
Shouts commands to urge horses and others to move quickly in dangerous situation.
Immediately reacts to danger, picks up gun, and positions himself to protect the group.
Engages in gunfire against attacking Indians alongside Griffin.
Shouts commands to whip horses and reacts quickly to danger by mounting, looking around, picking up a gun, and taking cover to defend against attackers.
Falls off horse when it steps in a hole during a pursuit.
Shoots the Indian chief during the conflict, causing injury and provoking mourning among the Indians.
Acknowledges Griffin's comment about the Indians not attacking defenseless men, showing a moment of reflection and acknowledgment of the complexity of the situation.
Carefully aims and shoots to wound the Apache chief, successfully causing the enemy to retreat.
Observes the situation tense and thoughtful, engages in assessing the outcome with Griffin.
Offers to shake hands with Griffin despite being rejected.
Helps the older man (Griffin) to his feet and suggests resting when he looks tired.
Thanks Griffin for staying and admits he might not have gotten out of the situation alone.
Admits to gambling, drinking, and killing a man in self-defense, emphasizing the need for self-care in a rough country.
Dismisses Griffin's criticisms angrily and refuses to engage further, using harsh language.
Admits to his faults and expresses regret about his past behavior and intentions toward Sally and Joe.
Speaks bitterly and cynically about their lack of protection and situation in the desert.
Waits for Griffin and cautiously observes surroundings, showing awareness of potential threats.
Acknowledges the seriousness of their situation, including lack of protection and danger from enemies, indicating realistic assessment.
Admits personal faults and motivations, showing self-awareness but also a previous lapse in judgment driven by ego.
Expresses regret over actions motivated by pride rather than practical concerns, suggesting prior lack of good judgment.
Presses water bottle upon Griffin and drinks with soldiers, showing calm and presence of mind during a tense situation.
Accurately estimates number of enemy warriors and participates in a rear guard action, demonstrating situational awareness and courage.
Reflects humbly on earlier mistakes and motivations, acknowledging his faults openly.
Shoots the chief (Victorio), effectively protecting the town.
Buys liquor (beer) for an Indian despite this being illegal, risking legal trouble.
Demonstrates some uncertainty, protesting and puzzled in discussions about the consequences of his actions.
Griffin defends Sam to Joe, affirming he knows the good in Sam and his love for the town.
Sam accepts the consequences calmly and says 'I probably have it coming to me.'
Sam is being arrested for giving liquor to an Indian, which is illegal and against town authority.
Accepts a farewell drink from Sally and thanks her sincerely.
Expresses regret for past mistakes and a desire to do right.
Shows vulnerability by admitting he wants Sally to believe in his change.
Is handcuffed and arrested for an act of kindness, indicating a misunderstood but well-intended action.
Seriously talks to Sally about the importance of her waiting for him when he gets out, showing awareness and planning.
Is handcuffed to a bar rail during a chaotic attack and does not escape or act to help, remaining passive.
Tries to free himself from bar rail under gunfire and urges Sally to run for her safety.
Unable to free himself from the rail and depends on Sally who refuses to leave.
Works with Sally to break his handcuffs and escape the saloon, urging her to come along.
Uses gun barrel as a lever to free his handcuffed hands from the rail.
After being freed with hands still shackled together, dashes across to doors and tries to find a way to escape.
Picks up a gun but then tosses it down, opting instead to pick up a piece of rail to use as a weapon or tool.
Knocks an Indian from his horse using a broken piece of bar rail while handcuffed.
Quickly moves toward the church to help others reach safety during an Indian attack.
Acknowledges the handicap of being handcuffed and insists on needing them removed to fight effectively.
Comments on not being able to fight with handcuffs on and suggests needing every man available.
Looks around alarmed upon hearing Glidden's assessment that the place is hard to defend with many windows and few defenders.
Speaks confidently about his own limitation (no knack at carpentry) but promptly offers to do a job he can handle, showing self-awareness and willingness to contribute effectively.
Approaches women and children in distress, performs magic tricks to entertain and divert them, successfully calming them and improving morale.
Urges Sally to engage with the children despite her reluctance, displaying leadership and social intelligence.
Performs magic tricks to entertain and comfort crying children and encourages Sally to sing with them, helping to lighten the mood.
Relieves Bob from guard duty, showing consideration for his fatigue.
Uses magic tricks to entertain and calm children, successfully diverting their attention and lifting their spirits.
Volunteers to relieve a tired guard, showing awareness of the physical demands and acting proactively.
Holds gun, takes guard duty seriously by stepping down and having Joe take over, showing responsibility and situational awareness.
Sits down by wounded Glidden and feels his head, showing care and attentiveness in a weary state.
Engages thoughtfully in a conversation about Apache beliefs and customs, showing awareness and some understanding.
Responds briefly and somewhat passively to Glidden's explanations without adding insight or elaboration, indicating limited contribution.
Observes and interprets enemy rituals and communicates the threat to Joe Madden, showing awareness and understanding of the situation.
Suggests taking Joe's place on lookout duty but expresses hesitation or uncertainty by saying 'I don't want you to take mine.'
Squats to talk to Sally, lifts her chin gently, offers personal concern and advice, calls her 'my girl'.
Speaks good-naturedly and attempts to reassure Sally about an impending difficult event, showing awareness and concern.
Advises Sally to protect the children and herself, indicating foresight and practical thinking.
Engages in seemingly calm and supportive interaction during tense circumstances, demonstrating emotional steadiness and confidence.
Positions himself with a rifle, remains tense and alert during the attack in the church.
Stays close to comrades and listens carefully in a high-pressure tense situation.
Fires twice as he moves forward during combat, helping neutralize threat to Pedro-Peter.
Runs to Pedro-Peter after attack to assist with his aid along with others.
Fires twice while moving forward to protect others and then runs to assist the wounded Pedro-Peter alongside Griffin and Joe, showing concern and readiness to help.
Crosses to Joe, Griffin, and others and speaks with spirit, motivating others despite the dire situation.
Fires his weapon twice while advancing forward during the conflict, demonstrating decisiveness and combat skill.
Runs to aid the wounded Pedro-Peter quickly and alongside others, showing situational awareness and teamwork.
Crosses over to speak with Joe, Griffin, and others with spirit, displaying confidence and leadership.
Joe acknowledges Sam as the best help a man could have in a bad spot.
Sam quickly raises rifle in response to potential threat but does not shoot, showing restraint.
Sam interacts with Pedro-Peter to understand why the Indian wants a doctor, showing willingness to communicate and cooperate.
Questions the trustworthiness of the enemy's word before agreeing to help.
Tries to stall by pretending to be a doctor to protect others.
Questions the reliability of the enemy's word before agreeing to help, showing cautious thinking.
Proposes stalling by pretending to be a doctor despite lacking real medical skills, indicating quick thinking and improvisation.
Admits he can't really help Victorio, revealing honesty but also the limits of his actual medical competence.
Acknowledges Joe's healing skills and supports him despite his own doubts.
Agrees to be Joe's deputy and play a supportive role, showing loyalty and cooperation.
Uses humor and self-deprecation when saying 'I'm a better bluffer' to lighten a tense situation.
Acknowledges Joe's medical skill and his own limitations by stalling and bluffing rather than pretending to be a doctor.
Accepts the deputy role from Joe and supports him despite lacking medical skills.
Uses bluffing to contribute to the plan rather than falsely claiming medical expertise.
Does not attempt to dishonestly claim medical knowledge but remains realistic about his abilities.
Hurries to open door despite warnings, trying to help Joe and others inside.
Expresses hope that Joe, a doctor, will help the wounded Indian, showing concern.
Carries Joe forward and moves to assist with care, stands ready with gun to protect others.
Engages in terse, serious talk with Sally in tense moment but shows concern in conversation.
Expresses uncertainty about how to tell others the bad news, showing sensitivity.
Commands people calmly to stand back and prepare to fire; encourages men to keep the fire going to prevent attackers from entering.
Rallies and motivates men actively to gather wood and reinforce the fire.
Commands others to stand back and prepares to fire when enemies arrive, showing leadership in a tense situation.
Directs others to gather wood and keep the doorway burning to prevent enemies from entering, demonstrating tactical awareness and initiative.
Rallies men to rush forward and break up firewood, displaying active engagement and effective coordination under pressure.
Rushes forward with men to break up church pews and gather wood to fuel the fire.
Fires gun upward to defend against attacking Indians inside the church.
Rushes on from the foreground during chaotic attack, showing proactive engagement.
Coordinates men to keep adding wood to the fire to hold back the attackers, actively fires at enemies, and helps drag a wounded man to safety.
Rushes forward to aid a wounded man and quickly gives an order to rip up the floor to address the situation.
Reacts promptly to auditory cues (bugle), hurries forward, and moves strategically with others amid chaos.
